learning.title: Weaving Evidence: Layering Claims, Context, and Caveats

questions.promptMd: Which slide note MOST appropriately communicates caveats without derailing the story?

answers.contentMd: Footnote: ‘Sample excludes <1% outliers; methods in appendix S1’
answers.feedbackMd: Concise caveat with pointer to detail.

answers.contentMd: Opening with three slides of methodology
answers.feedbackMd: Front‑loads detail and loses the room.

answers.contentMd: No caveats to keep it clean
A dense paragraph on every slide

questions.promptMd: True or False: Context (scope, baseline, time window) should precede the data to prevent misinterpretation.

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Frame the lens before the picture.

questions.promptMd: Where should alternative cuts live when likely to distract non‑expert executives?

answers.contentMd: Appendix with clean links from core slides
answers.feedbackMd: Preserves focus while enabling deep dives.

answers.contentMd: Inline with the main claim slide
answers.feedbackMd: Splits attention and weakens the main point.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Caveats should be as prominent as the main claim so they aren’t missed.
questions.rationaleMd: Relative prominence: claim > caveat; caveat accessible.

answers.feedbackMd: Over‑prominence can drown the signal. Keep caveats visible yet subordinate.
Correct. Make caveats easy to find without overshadowing the claim.
